wiki.text:
An 'adze' (; alternative spelling: 'adz') is an ancient type of edge
tool<ref>Any tool with a sharp cutting edge. Oxford English Dictionary: Edge-
tool, edged-tool.</ref> dating back to the stone age. Adzes are used for
smoothing or carving wood in hand woodworking, similar to an axe but with the
head mounted perpendicular to the handle. Two basic forms of an adze are the
hand adze, a short handled tool swung with one hand, and a foot adz, a long
handled tool capable of powerful swings using both hands - the cutting edge
usually striking at foot or shin level. The blade of an adze is set at right
angles to the tool's shaft (like a hoe or plane), unlike the blade of an axe
which is set in line with the shaft. A very similar (but blunt) tool used for
digging in hard ground is called a mattock.
